text: throughout our lives many of us will
need the treatment and care provided by
nurses during our first moments and
after our very first mishaps for routine
care and not so routine care throughout
our later years and even approaching the
very last days of our lives
worldwide there are more than 20 million
nurses and on average they account for
more than half of the health workers in
countries where data exists nearly 3/4
of nurses are women and in some cases
more than 90% this is a profession in
which women are very much on the front
line globally the highest concentration
of nurses is in Europe and although less
than a fifth of the world's population
lives in Europe it is home to a third of
the world's nurses
while the global average is 28.6 nurses
and midwives for every 10,000 people the
world's wealthiest countries benefit for
more than 88 and those in the lowest
income bracket that's close to a billion
people have just fine
so why are health workers so unequally
distributed one factor is that the
health workforce is increasingly mobile
with wealthier nations able to offer the
incentive of a more lucrative career
overseas whilst nursing is in fact one
of the most sought-after highly skilled
migrant professions
it is also one in which increasingly
women are migrating not as dependents
but his economic providers and nowhere
is this more visible than the
Philippines the world's largest exporter
of nurses and where eighty-six percent
of nearly 20,000 nurses will apparently
last year were women with a booming
population who are living longer than
ever before we have an insatiable demand
for health care and the world no doubt
needs doctors and nurses in greater
numbers than ever before
